climbs.name: Z Funk
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Kennan Harvey, Bill Gamble

content.description: Z Funk has more wide climbing! It starts out with nice hands and then gets startlingly wide under the ear and over the top of it. Fortunately it backs off again at the top.
content.location:
Walk left from the obvious A-frame of

Heat Pump

about 100 feet, and look for the splitter up the middle of the face. See the beta photo.

climbs.name: Tower Two
climbs.fa: Joel Coniglio, Cynda Crozier, and Charlie Fowler, 1997

content.description: Locate the largest tower in the area (GPS coordinates 38.1383, -108.8753), and begin on the northeast side of the tower. Climb up easy slab to a face with two bolts (crux). Once past the bolts, motor up more slab (possible mid-sized cam but not necessary) to the anchor.
content.protection: Draws and maybe a mid-sized cam.
content.location: It is on the furthest and biggest tower above the BLM campground.

content.description: This is the centermost tower of the trio. The book states this climb as 4th Class, but upon soloâ€™ing, the summit moves seemed a bit committing and felt more like lower to mid-5th Class to me. There is a bolted anchor on top with a rap to the NW. We climbed up the NE side or opposite the side seen from the road. Take a chossy, wide chimney slot up or a more secure Wingate slot up to the bench that guards the summit. There are two sport routes on this section which would be P1 of 2 for this tower.
content.protection: Some hand-sized cams will protect the moves to the summit. Bring a handful of draws for the first pitch if climbing the slab sport routes.
content.location: It is on the middle tower of the trio as seen from the road.

climbs.name: Thumbs Up Tower
climbs.fa: Joel Coniglio, Cynda Crozier, & Charlie Fowler, 1997

content.description: This ascends a remote tower with no crowds yet!
content.location: The route is on the East Face of this obvious, thumb-shaped tower.

content.description:
This needs some cleaning. It is not as classy as

Heat Pump

, which shares the anchor. It is good #6 practice, though.
content.location:
It shares an anchor with

Heat Pump

; across the meadow from Tower 2 and climbs the obvious A-frame crack. See the

Heat Pump

photo.

content.description: Heat Pump starts out with fingers to 0.75 to a nice ledge, then it goes full agro into a slot topped with a section of vertical offwidth. It is well worth bringing your big gear to get your pump on for this one.
content.location: Look for the twin offwidth cracks that make an A-frame and come together at a single anchor. It is pretty much directly across the meadow behind Tower 2. See the beta photo.

content.description: This climb is on the far right cliff band just behind the Towers. Climb up the acute, bigger-than-fists dihedral/slot into immaculate tight fists and hand crack all the way to the anchor! Edges and holds ease the grade of the climb, although the first 15 feet are a bit burly and blank (I couldn't fist jam this). Have fun. This thing is an awesome addition to a tower day if you climb the grade.
content.protection: #2 - #4 heavy on the big hands. I'd bring 1x #2, 4x #3, a 3.5 and 2x #4 for the start. The anchor is 4 3/4" stainless Powers with rap rings.
content.location: This climb is on the far left cliff band just behind the Towers. Approach as for Tower 2 (lookers rightmost tower), and the line is just behind.

climbs.name: 16 Candles
climbs.fa: Josh Smith, Kennan Harvey, Bill Gamble

content.description: 16 Candles is a wild route that starts out a bit hard and wide in a corner and then transitions to a steep, splitter, thin hands/fingers crack. If you kept right in the wide crack you could keep going up the corner to the top of the cliff but doing so would require an indecent number of 4s and 5s. Hint: before stepping left on the face reach inside the wide crack for hidden finger locks.
content.location:
It is just to the left of

Heat Pump

, across the meadow from Tower 2. See the beta photo.
